caption: Figure 1: Dataset distribution per each generator and language in our dataset
description: This figure shows the distribution of the dataset used in the paper, broken down by language and the large language model (LLM) used to generate the text.  It provides the counts of samples for each combination of language and LLM, giving a visual representation of how many samples were generated by each model in each language. This helps to understand the balance and coverage of the dataset across different LLMs and languages.

caption: Figure 2: F1 scores VS text sampling method used
description: This figure compares the F1 scores achieved by the model using different text sampling methods. The x-axis represents the sampling methods, while the y-axis displays the corresponding F1 scores.  It helps visualize how the choice of sampling technique impacts the model's performance in detecting AI-generated text, showing that greedy sampling methods yield better performance than other methods.

caption: Figure 3: F1 scores VS the generator’s texts
description: This figure visualizes the performance (measured by the F1 score) of the model in detecting AI-generated text across different large language models (LLMs).  It shows how well the model can distinguish between human-written and AI-generated text for various LLMs, providing insights into the model's effectiveness against different AI text generation techniques.

caption: Figure 4: F1 scores VS each domain’s texts
description: This bar chart visualizes the performance of the AI-generated text detection model across various domains.  The x-axis represents different text domains (e.g., abstracts, books, news, recipes, reviews, and wiki), while the y-axis displays the F1-score, a metric that combines precision and recall to assess the model's accuracy.  Higher F1-scores indicate better performance in identifying AI-generated text within a specific domain. The chart allows for comparison of the model's effectiveness across different text types.

caption: Figure 5: F1 scores VS adversarial method used in the input texts
description: This figure shows the performance of the model on text inputs that have been modified using various adversarial methods.  The x-axis lists different adversarial techniques applied to the input text, such as inserting extra paragraphs, using homoglyphs, or changing word spellings. The y-axis represents the F1-score, a metric that combines precision and recall to evaluate the model's performance.  Higher F1-scores indicate better performance. The bars in the chart show the F1-score for each adversarial method, indicating the model's robustness against different attacks.

caption: Figure 6: Accuracy VS length of input texts (sentence count)
description: This figure shows the relationship between the accuracy of AI-generated text detection and the length of the input text, measured in sentence count.  It visualizes how well the model performs at different text lengths.  The x-axis represents the number of sentences in the input text, and the y-axis represents the average word-level accuracy of the model's predictions.  Different colored bars correspond to different language-LLM pairs. This helps to analyze the model's performance across various text lengths and languages.
